title: How to Set Your Computer to Boot from USB Flash Drive

steps.title: Insert the bootable USB drive into a USB port.
steps.content: Insert the bootable USB drive into a USB port. As long as your USB drive is bootable , it'll be easy to boot from it when restarting your PC.

steps.title: Open your Windows Settings .
steps.content: Open your Windows Settings . You can do this by clicking the Start menu and selecting Settings or the gear icon.

steps.title: Click the Update & Security icon.
steps.content: Click the Update & Security icon. It's the two curved arrows at the end of the list.

steps.title: Click the Recovery tab.
steps.content: Click the Recovery tab. It's in the left panel.

steps.title: Click Restart Now under "Advanced Startup."
steps.content: Click Restart Now under "Advanced Startup." This is in the right panel.

steps.title: Click Troubleshoot on the blue screen.
steps.content: Click Troubleshoot on the blue screen. It's the icon with a screwdriver and a wrench.

steps.title: Click UEFI Firmware Settings.
steps.content: Click UEFI Firmware Settings . It's the option with a computer chip and a gear. If you don't have this option, you will need to restart your computer and get to the BIOS using your hardware's default key. As soon as you see the logo, you will need to hit either F1, F2, F6, F10, or Del to enter the BIOS menuâ€”the key you need to press should appear quickly on the screen (look for "Press X to enter setup").

steps.title: Click Restart.
steps.content: Click Restart . Your PC will now reboot into the BIOS/UEFI, which is where you'll tell your PC you want to boot from your USB flash drive.

steps.title: Find the Boot menu.
steps.content: Find the Boot menu. Every manufacturer has a different BIOS/UEFI setup, so you may have to browse around to find a menu called Boot, Boot Order, or Boot Options. You'll know you're in the right place once you see a list of different types of drives (such as optical drive, removable drive, USB drive, etc.). If you're using a Lenovo PC, for example, you'll select the Boot tab at the top. You may have to select a menu called Advanced , Storage , or System Configuration to find the Boot or Boot order menu.

steps.title: Change the boot order.
steps.content: Change the boot order. This area is going to look different depending on the manufacturer. Your goal is to make the device that's called something like "USB drive" or "Removable Drive" the first item in the boot order. If you don't see an option to change the order of the drives, you may just need to switch on a setting that enables "USB Boot" or similar.

steps.title: Save and exit.
steps.content: Save and exit. You can usually do this by selecting a tab or option called Save & Exit , or by pressing F10 . Once you confirm and exit, your PC will reboot from the USB drive. Be sure to remove the flash drive when you're done using it. Otherwise your PC will try to boot from it the next time you have to reboot.

steps.title: Insert the bootable USB drive into a USB port.
steps.content: Insert the bootable USB drive into a USB port. As long as your USB drive is bootable , it'll be easy to boot from it when restarting your Mac.

steps.title: Find out whether you have an Intel or Apple Silicon-based processor.
steps.content: Find out whether you have an Intel or Apple Silicon-based processor. The process to boot from a USB drive is different depending on the type of processor inside of your Mac. To find out: Click the Apple menu at the upper-left corner and select About This Mac . [1] X Research source If you see "Chip" followed by a name like "Apple M1" (or similar), you have an Apple Silicon chip. If you see "Processor" followed by a name that starts with "Intel," you have an Intel processor.

steps.title: Shut down your Mac.
steps.content: Shut down your Mac. If your Mac is on now, click the Apple menu and select Shut Down .

steps.title: Start up your Mac.
steps.content: Start up your Mac. The process is different depending on your processor: Apple Silicone: Press and hold the Power button until you see "Loading startup options." At that point, let go of the button. [2] X Research source Intel: Press and hold the Option key as you restart your Mac. Keep holding down the Option key until you see a list of available startup disks.

steps.title: Click your USB drive and click Continue (Apple Silicon) or the up arrow (Intel).
steps.content: Click your USB drive and click Continue (Apple Silicon) or the up arrow (Intel). Your Mac will now boot from the USB drive. This won't permanently change the boot order. The next time you start up your Mac, it'll start from your regular hard drive as normal.
